Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2017 02:33AM MTwoman wrote: Amyp, Under the BIRADS scoring system, 1 is negative findings (meaning found nothing) and 2 is b9 finding and a routine screening. Read more here: http://breast-cancer.ca/bi-rads/ About your question "Should I mention to the tech that I need the radiologist to look specifically for IBC symptoms or is this a standard" there seem to be key features of IBC on mri (read more here: http://www.ajronline.org/doi/pdf/10.2214/AJR.10.6157) so if you are going to a facility that routinely images breasts, and your mri is being read by someone who is experienced at reading breast mri, just let them do a good screening and let you know what it finds.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2017 02:29AM - edited Feb 16, 2017 03:11AM by MTwoman Csly, the only way to answer this question for certain is to continue following up. It very well could be benign (and most likely is), but it isn't only worthwhile to go to an appointment if you KNOW what the result it. It is also helpful to go when you DON'T know, because medical experts have the education, training and experience to be able to understand what the different possibilities could be and how to do further testing to determine what the actual cause is. No one here will be able to tell you what is happening in your breasts, we are only trying to share our experience and support. I would encourage you to go to your appointment and discuss your concerns so that you have peace of mind and understand what is going on inside your body. I meant that it is NEVER a waste of time to see a medical provider and get answers, even if they are benign answers. Your peace of mind is worth getting answers. Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2017 08:44AM MTwoman wrote: It may sound scary Csly, but it is benign. What is stromal breast fibrosis? The word stromal, just means "the whatever-stuff that this part of the body is made of". So it's a redundant word. "breast fibrosis" and "stromal breast fibrosis" mean the same thing. Same with "parenchymal", so parenchymal breast fibrosis, where parenchymal means "whatever-stuff this part of the body is made of". Basically, it's fibro fatty breast tissue with patchy breast fibrosis. That's great news!! So happy for your B9 results :D

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2017 09:44PM MTwoman wrote: Remali, I don't believe they do OncoType DX for a diagnosis DCIS, mainly as this is a test of whether CHEMO would be beneficial (the benefits outweigh the risks) and chemo is also not used for DCIS. The treatment choices are typically lx + rads + tamox/AI (if ER+) or mx + tamox/AI (if ER+) and in some specific cases perhaps + rads. Chemo isn't used as that is for cells that may have escaped the tumor and DCIS, by definition, is in situ (or doesn't leave the duct).

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2017 11:25AM MTwoman wrote: Semeagher, welcome to BCO! so sorry that you're here with breast health concerns. You're right that with the first mammo, they regularly have to figure out what is "normal" for some women, hence the call backs and re-imaging. Calcifications can happen naturally as we age, so some of them are "normal" and b9 and those typically present in specific patterns. There are other types of calcifications that are not "normal" and point to a potentially malignant process, these form different specific patterns. That your pattern was "indeterminate" means that it wasn't clearly one type or the other. BIRADS 4 is given when a finding has greater than a 2% chance of being malignant (less than that is BIRADS 3 and those are usually imaged on a closer interval schedule to assess for stability). The 'better safe than sorry' nature of BIRADS 4 means that 70-80% of biopsies in that category come back b9. If you have any other questions, please post them here and make sure to let us know how you're doing. Hoping that your biopsy comes back b9!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2017 12:32PM MTwoman wrote: Beckster, I respectfully disagree with Rebamacfan about crying. It isn't "important" to reduce crying episodes. There's no correlation between crying and your risk of recurrence or response to treatment. We all need to grieve about our diagnosis in different ways and in different times. Cry when you feel like it, just don't get stuck there. Sometimes letting yourself get your strong emotions out lets you refocus the rational part of your rational; which you will need to take in and process all the information that will be coming at you and then make decisions about your treatment. You can do this. It is a steep learning curve, but there's so many of us who've taken this journey and we're here to help you think of questions to ask your team and share our experiences and knowledge. Sending you warm thoughts and gentle ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2017 06:43PM MTwoman wrote: Rose882, age does indeed "have something to do with it" statistically. From this site http://www.breastcancer.org/risk/factors/age "Everyone alive is growing older. And as with many other diseases, your risk of breast cancer goes up as you get older. For example, according to the American Cancer Society, about 1 out of 8 invasive breast cancers develop in women younger than 45. About 2 out of 3 invasive breast cancers are found in women 55 or older. In fact, the aging process is the biggest risk factor for breast cancer. That's because the longer we live, there are more opportunities for genetic damage (mutations) in the body. And as we age, our bodies are less capable of repairing genetic damage." and Komen site presents this:  Freshmustard, so bc is possible in the 20's, yes, but age most certainly does have something to do with it and decreases the statistical probability significantly. Get it checked out, most definitively, but don't go too far down the "what if" road just yet.
Posts.Title: Slightly worried. Any advice/experiences Freshmustard Freshmustard

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2017 10:17PM MTwoman wrote: Rose, it isn't just the opinion of "some graph", it is the opinion of every top cancer treatment center in the country and it is fact (based on the numbers and ages of women who are diagnosed every year). I am not saying it isn't possible. I'm not saying it doesn't happen. I'm saying that statically, women in their 20's are significantly less likely than women in the 60's or 70's to get breast cancer. That the number of women per 100,000 is very very small in their 20's, that the number starts to increase at age 40 (which is why there is the recommendation for mammos starting at 40, unless someone has an increased personal risk). I did not "trust dr google". I used reputable sites like this one (the first link was from breastcancer.org) and other trustworthy sources.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2017 02:42AM MTwoman wrote: Hi Fraggle, Welcome and sorry you are here playing the dreaded "waiting game." I'm not sure which "scan" you are referring to, but various imaging technologies are better at picking up different types of tissue. Mammos are not as good with dense breast tissue. Xrays are good with bones, but not soft tissue. MRIs (using contrast dye) can note the difference in normal and abnormal tissue. A CT is limited in viewing tissue on one plane, while mri is not. Depending on lots of factors, doctors might want another type of imaging used to help them better understand the type of tissue they are dealing with. For example, if there is a palpable lump and dense breast tissue that doesn't allow for optimal viewing, they'll add another type of imaging to better "see" the lump. Using more than one type of technology gives experienced radiologists a lot of information, although it can be confusing for anyone not trained. Please contact your doctor and ask them to explain to you their assessment of why they believe your nodule behaved the way it did. Good luck and hoping for B9 results for you!

That means that, without any other factors that increase your personal risk, you have a very very slim chance of this being anything other than benign. Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2017 06:19AM MTwoman wrote: Sweetdee, so sorry that you are here concerned about your partner's health. There will be many women who will come along and provide you with information and support, but I'll start you out. If I understand what you are reporting correctly, her diagnosis is now IDC ER/PR+ and Her2+ or Triple Positive (Fish refers to a type of testing for the HER2 protein, btw, there is a forum for HER2+ bc). HER2+ bc tends to be more aggressive than HER2- bc and typically means that targeted therapy (like Herceptin or Perjeta) will be recommended. Targeted therapy is done in conjunction with chemo, so that is also a typical recommendation. The NCCN guidelines for a tumor greater than 1cm and lymph node positive call for "Adjuvant endocrine therapy + adjuvant chemotherapy with trastuzumab" You can find more here: http://www.tri-kobe.org/nccn/guideline/breast/english/breast.pdf

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2017 07:24AM MTwoman wrote: Your doctor will perform a breast exam and then (most likely) order imaging. While mammos are not typically ordered for young women (it doesn't see as well through young dense breast tissue), a combination of mammo (especially 3d) and US are the standard imaging tools for diagnosing breast "lumps", so that is what I would expect. If they cannot get good images using regular mammo, 3d mammo or mri might be recommended. IF what they see on imaging has specific characteristics, then they may recommend a biopsy. IF what they see has clearly b9 characteristics, then they may recommend short interval follow up. Either way, it is good practice to get a copy of your written imaging report and carefully read the impression and recommendation sections as well as noting the BIRADS score. That will give you quite a bit of good information about the likelihood that your lump is "bad". Please feel free to post any confusing language here and we'll help you sort it out. Good luck!

Even though I know it's scary, being called back in for a diagnostic only means they want to get more detailed imaging on a 'finding'. Hope this helps put it in perspective:  So you are in the 10% of women who get a mammo and then get called back for a diagnostic. 75% who get diagnostic are then told routine or 6 month follow up. 25% then get biopsy. Of that small number, approximately 80% have benign findings. So you are still early in the process. Please try to remain calm and follow up with your team. I know it's hard. There is a thread for how to deal with the anxiety here: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/83/topics/855477?page=1#idx_14 Good luck for B9 results!

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2017 11:26PM MTwoman wrote: Actually, a screening mammo has only a couple of views (angles at which they take the image). If you are referred for an ultra sound, what is typical is that you get a diagnostic mammogram (more views from different angles) in conjunction with an ultrasound as the two imaging technologies combined provide for better diagnostics. If, after those 2 technologies are applied, then sometimes, women might go in for an mri. During an mri, they use a dye and watch how the dye is both taken in and then "washed out" of an area. The pattern of uptake and washout can be very telling to an experienced radiologist and things in dense breast tissue can be "seen" that can't be seen with mammo or us. They are doing what they should, please don't be alarmed at that. Also, there are radiation techs that typically perform the us, but it should be read by the radiologist as well (hence a potential delay). Sometimes, the tech can't quite find what they need to easily and they call in the radiologist to take a look. All of that takes extra time. Good luck and hoping for B9 results for you!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2017 12:37AM MTwoman wrote: I am so sorry that your Mother is going through bc again! I am in agreement with the others above, I believe that her age (and RBC status) is affecting the options. I also, very respectfully and gently, suggest that you listen to your Mom and what she wants. It sounds like you want her to have all of the information, and that you'd prefer a more aggressive approach. But we all need different amounts of information. Some women need more, some don't respond well to more. And quality of life should NOT be underestimated. My father had laryngeal cancer. Due to his age, the treatment was surgery plus rads. If they had been really clear about the side effects of rads, I'm not sure he would have done it. He was already 80 and, after 2 bouts of hospitalization with aspiration pneumonia, they realized his airway wasn't protected when he ate or drank any longer (se from rads). He had a peg tube the last year of his life and it was awful for him. He could smell, but never taste the food that he had loved his whole life. To spend the last years that way is something that he never would have chosen had he known. The cancer didn't kill my father, but the side effect of one of the treatments left him with a life he never would have chosen and once he realized it would never get better, he gave up and passed away. I know the situations are very different, but I hope that helps think about the toll that treatment can take and the impact of that toll. She does need to have information on treatment options; but if she and her doctors decide to go less aggressive than you'd like, please do trust her judgment. ((hugs))

There is a great and comprehensive thread where women have discussed the lx vs mx question. I'm going to post that thread here so that you can read through it and then ask any lingering questions there: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/68/topics/806074?page=1 You might also want to ask about women's reactions to an AI. The "hormone therapy" is very different from taking "hormones". As you are post menopausal, you'll be recommended to take an Aromatase Inhibitor. Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2018 07:57PM MTwoman wrote: Chelleb, You absolutely need to grab ahold of yourself! Try taking several deep breaths, holding each one to a count of 8, then release to a count of 10. Now again.  Okay, now you need to focus on what you KNOW to be true, NOT what you fear. What you know is that you have had several professionals look at your breast and your skin and tell you that you do NOT have IBC. Your derm even gave you a diagnosis "post erythema". Every time your mind starts to go to the "what if"/scary place, you need to grab ahold of it and tell yourself (out loud actually works better) "I have seen medical providers about this and I DO NOT HAVE IBC" and then you need to distract yourself with something else to get your mind off of this persistent worry. Clean something, needle work, knit, go for a long walk or run, learn breathing or yoga, binge-watch something, or do some relaxation (warm bath, soothing music, chamomille tea, lavender oil/candle). I am glad you are back on your anti anxiety medication, but it seems like it would be very useful to you to also start working with a therapist who is experienced in helping folks with anxiety. It will take over your life if you don't get it in check. Best of luck!

Posts.Content: May 10, 2017 11:41AM MTwoman wrote: I agree with MelissaDallas, Sjacobs and Mustlovepoodles. I'll add that your traumatic response to your father's cancer diagnosis and treatment sounds significant. In fact, I would suggest that you give thought to seeing a counselor about it. There are many effective treatments for trauma (like EMDR) that can allow you to process these events as information, instead of a traumatic trigger. It is really helpful, when we have the ability to sort out what are real concerning symptoms and then be able to let go of the fear when a reasonable diagnostic workup has been performed and diagnosis sorted out. Sometimes we do have a feeling in our 'gut' and need to be able to trust that feeling and pursue a second opinion or additional diagnostics. When every twinge is perceived as "red alert, it's cancer"; then you'll live your life in constant fear and not really be able to 'trust your gut' because it will always be saying the same thing. That is really bad for your overall health, not to mention quality of life. Please take this in the spirit in which it was intended. Anxiety sucks!

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2017 04:03PM MTwoman wrote: Cliffyw, you can always see the MO at MSK for a second opinion consult. It is actually quite common for an MO to create a treatment plan that is then executed elsewhere, so you are NOT committing to treatment at MSK. Take all of your wife's info (the binder with all reports, images, etc) and get the MO's opinion on what treatment they would recommend. You could also have a discussion on the article(s) and what impact they make on those recommendations. If you here the same recommendations from both MOs then hopefully you feel reassured about the course of treatment. If they differ, then you can ask questions about why and make a well informed decision then (or seek a third, tie breaker).

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2017 11:37PM MTwoman wrote: Hi 53Nancy, welcome to BCO, although I'm so sorry you've had to join our ranks. I'll briefly answer your questions, knowing that others will come along and give you some more detailed answers. DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) by definition stays in the ducts and isn't invasive. The IDC or invasive ductal carcinoma is invasive, meaning it could have spread. IDC is commonly found together with DCIS, but the DCIS will not alter your treatment as any treatment for IDC will most surely take care of the DCIS. Your IDC will be the focus. Most likely, you will have more scans ordered (like a CT) to look at your lymph nodes or other areas of your body to see if there has been spread. Once they have those answers back, they can give you your stage, which also effects your treatment. Her2 neu over-expression drives rapid growth, so negative means that your cancer cells are not over expressing HER2 neu. (That just means that you won't be receiving a targeted therapy that focuses on HER2+ bc.) I would recommend that you join the IDC forum and post a brief description (as you did above) in order to connect to others with similar stats and to find women with whom you can discuss treatment options. There is so much knowledge, experience and support here. Please do let us know how we can help! sending you gentle ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2017 01:12PM MTwoman wrote: Esperanza, given your prior history with less than stellar recommendations from the local imaging center, coupled with your other health conditions, I don't blame you being reluctant to have them investigate further. I think your idea of seeking a breast specialist's recommendation (I would absolutely send/bring all copies of images and written imaging reports for his/her review) is a good one. Worst case scenario, he/she recommends the same thing, best case, he/she orders additional imaging (at another locale) and decides it is in fact b9 and does not recommend biopsy. Either way, you'll have more confidence in that person's recommendations and you can give them your medical history to insure that all appropriate precautions are taken on your behalf. I would encourage you to "travel" a bit (the closest major center) to insure that the breast specialist sees a large enough number of women to focus on breasts exclusively. You may not be able to get in asap, but it would be worth the extra drive. Good luck for b9 results!

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2017 10:36AM MTwoman wrote: I agree with cive, unless you think that you won't be able to enjoy your vacation for worrying. Describe what you've clearly stated above and get their impression. They have all your records and have seen your prior images, so they can give you good direction. While a "faint oval nodule" does not immediately sound concerning, the combination of your new symptoms and your prior imaging study may change their thoughts. Typically, they don't do follow up scans earlier than the initial recommendation as the designated time means they can determine if the finding is stable. But when you add additional symptoms, they may reassess. Good luck!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2017 04:39PM MTwoman wrote: Tnackt, try your best not to be nervous, this is a reasonable diagnostic step given that you presented with pain in your breast. http://www.imaginis.com/breast-cancer-diagnosis/overview-of-breast-cancer-diagnosis-decision-process 90% of screening mammos are, everything looks okay, return for a routine mammo in a year of the remaining 10% (who get referred for a diagnostic workup) 75% are told, everything looks okay, return in 6 months for a re-check of the remaining 25% (who are sent for a biopsy) 80% are told everything is okay, with a benign or atypical finding and given return follow up instructions. So you have only gotten to step 1. There is a 90% chance that you won't even advance to the next step. Try not to worry too much. Sending you good wishes for B9 findings!

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2016 04:23PM MTwoman wrote: I had DCIS, and originally chose lumpectomy. After a follow up MRI found more (multi-focal) DCIS in other quadrants, I had to go back and get MX to get the rest of it. You will give them permission to perform a procedure (whichever one you decide, in agreement with your surgeon). They will perform that surgery only (removing the tissue that they determine needs to come out to get good margins). If they determine, after pathology, that they didn't achieve the margins they need for good prognosis, then they will discuss options with you and again, you have to give them permission for the procedure that you chose. You are a very important part of your treatment team! I won't work with any provider who doesn't acknowledge and treat me that way. Their expertise and guidance, but your body, your choice.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2017 05:57PM MTwoman wrote: goingforgold, mammo isn't "useless", but each imaging technology has types of tissue/findings that it is good at "seeing" and those it isn't. That's why it is common for diagnostic protocols to include 2 different imaging technologies together. I would get the written copies of your reports (in case you don't already have them), and the images on cd (you are legally entitled to that) to take with you to your bs. He/she may want to have the same imaging techniques repeated, or may want to do 3D mammo or mri (which are both better at seeing through dense breast tissue). The mri isn't routinely used as a front line imaging tech as it is very sensitive (sees lots of things other imaging doesn't) but isn't specific (sees lots of things other than bc). The numerous findings then leads to biopsies, the vast majority of which are b9. (so $$ and lots of anxiety). Meet with the bs, take a list of your questions and maybe another person to be able to listen and remember for you (hard to retain info properly when we're really anxious) or recording device. Good luck!
Posts.Title: They said it's not cancer but what is it? And what now? Goingforgold MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2017 12:42PM MTwoman wrote: Hopeful, about the mammo. the recommendation is first one at 40 years old because younger women tend to have denser breasts which makes that technology less effective. This may factor into the negative recommendation for mammo from the OB NP. Maybe talk to the GP about your concerns and ask for his/her recommendation. There are other technologies that are more effective for dense breasts, but without a "finding" (i.e. lump or other concern IN your breast) not sure what will be investigated, AND insurance will most likely not cover it. For example, when women present with a lump (like I did at 38), they are referred for a diagnostic mammo (this has more views than a screening mammo) coupled with an US (ultrasound "sees" tissue differently, so the combination provides additional information). Younger women on these boards have been monitored using other technology, depending on the situation, their presenting issue, family history etc. So glad that you are feeling more at ease and good luck at your GP's next week!

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2017 03:00AM MTwoman wrote: Hi Buffy, Your biopsy tissue should have been sent to pathology for the hormone receptor status (estrogen and progesterone). HER2 neu (a tyrosine kinase protein receptor) is typically sent out to a specialty lab, so comes back a bit later. These are the hormones that "feed" tumors. If the ER comes back +, then typically, after surgery, there is a follow up treatment with either Tamox or an AI. HER2 also has a targeted treatment (Herceptin), but it is not typically used in DCIS. I do believe that there are studies being conducted about whether it is useful and whether the risks/benefits make sense for DCIS (I believe there are ladies on these boards who had DCIS and used it). You should get a written copy of your pathology report for your own records. As for extensiveness, I had what is called multi-focal/mulit-centric DCIS. That means that they found several tumors in different quadrants. It is not uncommon, especially for certain architecture types. I had cribriform, papillary and micro-papillary architecture. My understanding is that cribriform poses a higher risk for multi-focal disease. That is actually why I had an MRI after my lx. I got a second opinion on my pathology from a specialist in DCIS and he suggested due to my age and the architecture, that I should look for more disease before I underwent radiation. (that news came the exact day before I was scheduled to start my first radiotherapy mapping appointment) I paused my rad treatment and went for mri, which found 2 other areas of concern, which when biopsied also turned out to be DCIS. They recommended mx at that point, as I had very close margins on my original lx (and had thrown a hematoma from that surgery). They did pathology on the mx tissue as well, and found that the 2 other lumps were similar in architecture, no micro-invasion or idc, but areas of comedo necrosis were present. Genetic testing is done to determine if you have any gene abnormalities that typically result in a higher risk for certain types of cancer (BRCA 1 or 2 are the most well known, but there are numerous others). This is not done on your biopsy tissue, but is a separate procedure. You should get genetic counseling to help you decide the risks benefits of this and to help understand what the results mean if you do proceed with this. These results sometimes impact people's treatment decisions as they can change your future risk. I know it is a lot to take in right now, but keep asking any questions you have. Either/both here and with your treatment team. The more you know, the better decisions you can make for yourself. It is overwhelming, and no one minds repeating or restating things. If you do have questions for your team, write them down and then either write or record their answers so you can go back over it and refresh your memory. It is amazing how some things can slip right out of the brain when it is overwhelmed. Sending you healing light and ((hugs)).

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2017 12:57PM MTwoman wrote: Molasses, BRCA testing is not designed to tell you if you will or will get bc. It is especially not designed to tell you if you do or do not have bc. It is designed to tell you if you have genetic anomalies that have/have not been linked to an increased risk of getting bc (or other cancers). It is NOT intended to replace mammograms, mris or us. I don't believe with BRCA testing you would say you have a "false negative or false positive". You either have the gene mutation or you don't. That being said, they are continuing to collect evidence suggesting additional gene mutations other than just BRCA convey increased risk for bc. I don't believe this site encourages BRCA testing as a replacement for actual monitoring for disease, more as additional personal risk information. Can you provide a link where you read that BRCA testing is a "benchmark for bc" and should replace imaging?

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2017 02:29PM MTwoman wrote: Hopeful, Based on the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (under the ACA) here are the guidelines for what must be offered with no out of pocket charge, as far as BRCA risk assessment and genetic counseling "The USPSTF recommends that primary care providers screen women who have family members with breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer with one of several screening tools designed to identify a family history that may be associated with an increased risk for potentially harmful mutations in breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 or BRCA2). Women with positive screening results should receive genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, BRCA testing." It is always good to verify coverage with your individual insurance company, but right now, the law of the land requires that this be offered. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2017 03:34PM MTwoman wrote: want2know, so sorry you're here with breast health concerns. As far as the biopsy, I felt some discomfort during the procedure, but nothing that some ice and a few over the counter pain relievers didn't fix. I didn't even need those the next day. Please make sure and ask your center for little ice packs if they have them (they are small and round and fit neatly inside your bra for maximum comfort). Ask for a couple so that one can stay in the freezer and one on the site. Each lab is different in how long results take, so be sure to ask them when they are expected and if they'll tell you over the phone or if you'll need to be seen in person (facilities vary in this regard). Also, ask them to send you a copy of your pathology report and ask for a copy of your images for your own personal records. Either way, having a set of them lets you provide them to a future different imaging center or medical provider as needed. The other thing you might discuss with your provider is genetic testing. Given the family history you've described above, it doesn't seem out of the question. And could justify increased future monitoring. If you get any confusing language, if you post it here we can help you better understand. Sending you warm wishes for B9 results and gentle ((Hugs))

I've also noticed the " inverse ratio to number of posts versus likelihood of actually being diagnosed" that MelissaDallas referred to. This isn't really good for anyone, women/men currently going through treatment, survivors, family members trying to support/advocate for those they care about OR even for those who have anxiety about their health (but have B9 results). It perpetuates myths that aren't useful " I'd love to tell others how my symptoms that seemed to seriously mimick BC". Anxiety can be all consuming if you let it; especially if you feed it. I would actually recommend not going to a breast health site, but working on the anxiety. There is a forum http://anxietyforum.net/ that will let you interact with others who are also dealing with different types of anxiety. That site is actually more useful for your ongoing mental health and anxiety reduction than a breast health site, where you are going to consistently be focused on your breast and " Nothing came out on US so I ask the question, what is causing all this? Why would I feel this? I never drink coffee, no caffeine. So I believe I'll be having an MRI in maybe 3 months time ( I dont have insurance and pay out of pocket but they're expensive)... I would like to advice others while I'm still having severe Breast symptoms.." You need to work on letting this go and following up appropriately as recommended. If you don't have one, now might be a great time to get a therapist who can help bring you more peace around health issues. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2017 11:44AM MTwoman wrote: Willow, Remembering back to my first diagnostic screening, and I'm not sure I asked anything. :/ I did know that if there were any questionable findings that I was supposed to get a surgical consult, so I did push for that (I actually had discussed my situation with an MD friend, who had given me a BS name in case I needed it). But you will want to know your BIRADS score, which should correspond to their recommendation. For diagnostic screening, BIRADS 3, 4 or 5 are your 'options', and 4 or 5 mean biopsy. Typically, 3 means a shorter interval follow up to monitor for changes as the chances of it being bc are very very small. If you are confused about any recommendation, that is when I'd have them explain why they are recommending what they are. Best of luck for b9 findings!

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2017 06:35PM MTwoman wrote: roopanrk, take a breath. Some of what you've posted is a bit conflicting, so it's hard to know how to respond. "result BIRADS 4 and reported BIRADS 5" doesn't make sense. So, BIRADS 4 biopsies typically come back anywhere from 70-80% benign. "BI-RADS category 5 is usually reserved for lesions having a 95% probability of malignancy. After biopsy the average rate of carcinoma in category 5 biopsies is about 75-97%." http://breast-cancer.ca/bi-rads/ But even then, as you see from the stats, it isn't cancer until the pathology report says "cancer". At that point, there still is no "life expectancy" info because breast cancer isn't just breast cancer. It is: DCIS, IDC. ILC, IBC etc etc and there are grades (how disorganized the cells are) and receptors (whether estrogen or progesterone "feed" the cancer) and HER2 expression (a sign of rapid replication) etc etc as well as stages (how big is the area of cancer, has is spread to lymph nodes or other areas of the body) before "life expectancy" can be discussed. Try to take this one step at a time. First, get the biopsy report back. Then, have your Mom plan a consultation with the doc to discuss the results and ask questions. Good luck!

If you read here: http://marathon.csee.usf.edu/Mammography/DDSM/ddsm_terminology.html which is the database for breast density and lesion descriptions, the mass shape is one description and the mass margins is another. See the diagrams here: http://www.oncoprof.net/Generale2000/g04_Diagnosti... The difference is one is a description of the shape of the mass and the other is a description of the border or margin of the mass.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2017 07:06PM MTwoman wrote: Hi Virgo73, so sorry that you've had to join our club, but so glad that you found us. There will be others along shortly to give you more info (and support), but I wanted to let you know that the DCIS part of your bc will not be the focus, as anything that is needed to treat the IDC portion will most certainly take care of the DICS as well. The DCIS could affect how much tissue needs to be removed (sometimes women may have a large amount of DCIS and a smaller amount of IDC) so may affect your surgical recommendations, but the dcis will not alter your other treatment recommendations. The information that you'll be looking for next will be the hormone receptor status, her2 status etc, from your IDC. Those characteristics will inform your treatment as well as the size of the area and extent of involvement. I think the thoughts about a bmx is common initially, but that won't reduce your risk to 0%, so you should be aware of your personal risk profile to make the best decision for you. And while not having the BRCA is certainly good news, only about 10-11% of bc has been linked to the genetic mutations that we know of so far. Sending you warm thoughts and gentle ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2017 05:45PM MTwoman wrote: breastchangesfear, Cysts are common findings on us. They want to aspirate it because that is the typical thing to do. They aspirate it, send the fluid to cytology to make sure that the cells are b9 (as they expect them to be) and frequently the cyst collapses and resolves on it's own. Please try to calm yourself so that you can really hear what your provider is telling you. In his expert opinion, he believes it to be a simple cyst, but out of abundance of caution and to follow protocol, he will aspirate it. Try to focus on the good news and not on your fear of what "could be". You can do it!

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2017 11:31AM MTwoman wrote: Momofollie, take a deep breath. You said it yourself, " she thought it was probably a cyst or potentially an ingrown hair. However, because of the location she referred me for an ultrasound and mammogram tomorrow afternoon." You are working yourself up over "what ifs" when your doctor already told you she thought it was a cyst or ingrown hair. Tender breasts for 3 days are most likely from cycling hormones. Here is the breast cancer diagnostic process:  Notice that of the women who get a diagnostic workup, 75% are given b9 results and returned to either routine or 6 month follow up. The other 25% of the women (who get a diagnostic workup) are referred to get a biopsy. Of those women, 80% are told they have a benign or atypical result and they can also return to either routine or an increased screening regimen. So you are getting WAY off base from what the doctor who saw you thinks and what the statistics actually say at this point in your diagnostic process. Try to stay distracted and keep yourself busy. Hold on to what you know, not what you fear. Good luck for b9 results!

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2017 10:43AM MTwoman wrote: Mel, Welcome to BCO! I am sorry you're here with breast health concerns, but I am glad you found us. Now, all breast surgeons are technically general surgeons. There isn't an actual designation (like there is for PS). But how much of their practice focuses on breast surgery (as opposed to, say, appendectomies or cholecystectomies) will give you quite a bit of information. If they've done some sort of specialized training, or include staying current on new breast surgery developments through their annual continuing medical education; then you can feel more secure. You can find out about how much breast work they do by calling the office and asking. If you don't like their answer, get a referral for someone else. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2017 05:27PM MTwoman wrote: sayhey, This is not something that you have to rush, talk about this when you schedule your next appointment with your new gyn. I do understand that when another member of the family has cancer, it tends to make others more anxious about their own health. But educating yourself, like talking to your doctor about your own breast health, may be useful. Young women's breasts are typically dense, and prone to change, have discomfort or go through fibrocystic changes. Your gyn may be able to discuss this with you and give you information to help alleviate your fears. Please look carefully at these statistics to help you feel less anxious while you wait for your appointment:  Please note that for the group of women between the ages of 20-34, there is only a 1.8% risk of getting a breast cancer diagnosis. That isn't a 1.8% for 21 year olds, that is a 1.8% total risk spread across the whole group, which means that your risk at 21 is phenomenally low. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2017 10:30AM - edited Nov 21, 2017 10:30AM by MTwoman Okay AnxietyGirl, you need to stop and take a deep breath. Now take one more and hold it. Okay, now slowly let it out. Focus on what you know to be true: "the numbers that are in my favour - 80% of biopsies are negative for cancer, breast cancer in your 30s isn't terribly common, the doctor said 5-50% of cancer which means 50-95% chance that it isn't" NOT what you fear. When you start to go down that 'what if' rabbit hole, stop yourself and focus on what you know. Keep yourself busy with Thanksgiving festivities, bake or cook something that requires your full attention. Deep clean something. Go for a long walk. You'll get your results soon and then you can respond to something real, not something imagined/feared. Your anxiety today won't change those results, so it doesn't help you at all. Please do try to let it go.

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2017 05:25PM MTwoman wrote: Okay Erika, take a big deep breath. You did the right thing in reporting your new and/or concerning breast symptom to your doctor. Your doctor did an exam, and does not believe that there is cause for alarm. That should help you feel a bit better. Also, 20 year olds are at extraordinarily low risk for BC. See chart below:  Please notice that you are in the age bracket that includes 15 years worth of women and represents only 1.8% of the women diagnosed with bc in the US. So it is possible, just very statistically unlikely. Also note, mammograms are not typically used in 20 year olds, even if there is an issue, as their breast tissue is normally too dense for the mammo to "see" through. An ultra sound would be a more appropriate imaging technology for you. Now, fibrocystic breasts are more typical in younger women and can be painful. Please just take one step at a time. If the pain continues, follow up as your doctor directed. You also may want to check out this thread about b9 causes of breast pain: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/83/topics/857903?page=1#post_5028462 Good luck!

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2017 06:50PM MTwoman wrote: 53Nancy, Sorry your concerns have gotten sort of buried in the ongoing OP's post. Let me try to answer some of them. Hopefully others will come along to answer the rest. Is it possible that microcalcifications were present before but not seen because of breast density? I believe that is possible. I have seen comments that, even though patients were told the area was considered contained, a mastectomy was suggested. I'm not sure what you mean by "contained". If you mean Ductal Carcinoma In-situ (meaning hasn't yet become invasive disease, i.e hasn't left the duct) then yes, I am one of them. The reason that mx was recommended for me was that after lx for a palpable lump, I had an mri that identified 2 other areas of concern in another quadrant of my right breast that also turned out to be dcis. Multi-focal/multi-centric dcis frequently comes with the recommendation for mx. Is it possible for SOME of the microcalcifications to be cancerous, while others are not? While there are both malignant and non-malignant causes for micro-calcs, I do not know if they are typically found mixed together in the same area of the breast. Maybe someone else knows that. Are there options other than mammogram for breast scannning, as I have read so much about mammograms actually being the cause of calcifications spreading? Let me address the second part of your question first. Mammograms do not cause the spreading of calcifications. If they did, the majority of women would present with very large areas of calcs (as the recommended age for women to begin mammos has been 40 (or before with higher risk) and would represent years of them before being diagnosed); and that isn't the case. So that information is false. As to additional options for imaging, there are ultra sound (which is better at seeing specific types of 'findings' in the breast) and mri (which is very sensitive, but not specific to bc, so creates the situation where many b9 things need to be biopsied). It is typical, when a finding can't be well enough identified through mammography, to add ultra sound, as 2 imaging types provide better information than just one alone. When mammo+us can't make a determination (or can't see well enough through dense breast tissue) then an mri may be recommended. That is the radiologist's job, to determine which imaging technology is best for the task and to evaluate the findings overall.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2017 04:08PM MTwoman wrote: Okay Lissaidell, I know it's frustrating, but take a deep breath. It is hard to tell from your summary above (instead of the actual language used in a report) exactly what happened. It sounds as if you have a summary of the procedure, but perhaps not your pathology? Typically, the pathology report comes separately, names and lists the sites samples and then what was found in each sample. re: " It also states that she didn't do a mammo after because of my age" that is because younger breast tissue is typically denser and mammos don't "see" well through dense tissue. It isn't "an assumption" as in 'we won't bother, she's too young to have bc', but an assumption that mammos aren't very useful in women your age. It sounds like, based on your comment " My family is not like what they think is normal cancer hit fast and hard" that you have had genetic testing (family carries a genetic mutation) and that is why you were surprised at your initial pathology? If that is the case, and you're being closely followed due to your increased risk, then why not call your doctor's office to sit down and review the procedure and pathology and make a plan for next steps. Hoping your doctor can help give you some more answers!

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2017 07:28AM MTwoman wrote: soccer04, I understand the link between HPV and certain cancers. The part of your post that I was responding to was "from what I have read and videos I have watch the hpv virus can spread anywhere ie. neck, throat, brain etc . and turn into different types of cancer..". People are exposed to the virus through skin to skin contact with another infected person and can be contracted in various places in the body through contact (i.e. to the throat - through oral sex, to the anus - through anal sex, to the genitals - through sex etc). Genital warts are caused by one of the HPV viruses and warts can be spread locally by autoinoculation; for example, no shaving around warts. Otherwise they don't spread body-wide. There are over 100 varieties of HPV, and people are not limited to just one type, so precautions should be taken even if both partners have HPV.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2017 10:45AM MTwoman wrote: Rachael, rads are typically given to women who opt for LX, and sometimes given after MX. The "pill" for years to come is most likely Tamoxifen or an AI, which is anti-hormonal treatment typical for ER/PR+ bc. And while rads do tend to "wear you out" (it accumulates over the course of the 6 weeks), it is the NCCN standard to make sure no bad cells were left behind and reduce the chance of a local recurrence. The pain you talk about may be nerves that were cut during surgery. It is unfortunately unavoidable for some nerves to be involved, depending on where the lump is. Please do talk with your doc to get a better idea of what's going on in your treatment, so that you can start getting your questions answered. Do they have a nurse navigator? They can be extremely helpful! Good luck!

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2017 04:30PM MTwoman wrote: busser, mammos are a piece of cake. Uncomfortable cake certainly, but the discomfort is relatively short lived for most women. The machine has "plates" (think flat, square glass plates, not dinner plates) that will squish whichever boob is placed in between them. They will try to get as much breast tissue in between the plates as possible. You lean into the machine to aid in that process. Then they squeeze. It is uncomfortable. They ask you to hold your breath while they take the images. As soon as they've taken the images the plates separate. So the discomfort doesn't last longer than you can hold your breath. Then they get a different view. Same procedure. The diagnostic process has several different views (screening has fewer). If it helps, this is the bc diagnostic process:  Notice that 75% of women having a diagnostic workup are either told to return to regular or shorter interval follow up. Of the 25% that are referred for biopsy, 80% have b9 or atypical follow up. Math is on your side right now. Try your best to just take one step at a time. Good luck for b9 results!
Posts.Title: Two days until appointment busser211 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2017 11:47AM MTwoman wrote: I agree with Michelle_in_cornland, if 6 separate radiologists had the same opinion, I'd take that as a good sign that you'll get b9 results. I'm not sure where NotVeryBrave got those statistics. From the source that I typically go to, I find " A birads 4b has 36% chance of malignancy." Read more here: http://breast-cancer.ca/bi-rads/ If it makes you feel any better, there are 'things' that grow in breasts that aren't bc. Also, 70-80% of biopsies come back B9. Given the vast differences in opinion, a biopsy is the appropriate step. " I really want to beg for them to just do the excisional biopsy and lymph nodes and get a step ahead instead of then waiting AGAIN for that." An excisional biopsy and especially any lymph node (SNB) removal would not be a good first step. There are risks that come along with those interventions that far outweigh the risk of an unidentified mass. The risk of lymphedema is present, even if they just remove 1 lymph node. I know that this has come as a surprise and that you are scared and angry, but take the first step to get a biopsy and pathology results before rushing too far ahead. Hoping they get you scheduled quickly so that you can get your results back quickly as well. Good luck for b9 results.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2017 04:06PM MTwoman wrote: Masterful, I agree with Wrenn and Kicks. I will go further to say I was a bit confused when you wrote " I decided I want to see a breast surgeon now after all because I need another opinion. I am not concerned really with this increased activity in my left breast... I am concerned about the lump but somehow that becomes the issue" and "The MRI and Ultrasound radiologist also dont want me to get another biopsy because they are afraid it will mess up the image but I am thinking to just have another biopsy". It sounds as if you want to ignore the medical professionals who evaluated you based on their education and expertise in reading breast mri. Now I do realize that women frequently become hyper-sensitive to threats to their unborn babies. That is absolutely normal, and I think reasonably pursuing answers to your medical questions is important. I just think that there is a line between advocating for yourself and demanding medical providers do what you tell them to, instead of what is the standard of care. There are reasons, based on science/medicine that dictate when biopsies are done, or when additional imaging is done. And then there are reasons for what follow up is recommended. When you jump from one to another without the proper education/training/experience, you may be hamstringing the very people trying to provide you with good care. I, therefore, would go into the expert's office and provide the symptom history, scans and reports that you have to date and ask HIS opinion.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2017 04:38PM MTwoman wrote: hopeful, what you may be experiencing is something called sampling bias. Mostly the women who stuck around (or returned) to post on these boards also eventually had bc. The vast majority who were diagnosed with a B9 breast event don't stick around or return. So you are only seeing the "worst case" scenario, not the thousands of women who heard "B9", came back once to say "woohoo, thanks for the support" (or didn't return) and were never heard from again. Try to just focus on one step at a time. SO happy you got an earlier appointment and can start to get some concrete answers. Waiting is the worst! hugs

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2017 11:37AM MTwoman wrote: 19eileen, Welcome to BCO! I am so sorry your find yourself here with concern and confusion about your breast health status. What is sounds like to me is that your results were "discordant". What that means is that the biopsy did not match the expected results. Did you get an actual copy of your written report of the pathology? When they "find" something on imaging, your pathology results should then clarify what it is, i.e. radial scar, fibroadenoma etc (in this case that wouldn't match the spiculated description, but just as an example). It shouldn't say "nothing found" (i.e. normal breast tissue), as that indicates that they may have missed the targeted sampling area when they did the biopsy. When someone gets discordant results, the process can be different at different facilities, but should include a review by experts of both images and pathology to make a recommendation (re-imaging, re-biopsy). Sometimes, if an area is difficult to sample, there is a wire placed or clip placed so that they are sure to sample the right area. Did they do that for you? It didn't sound that way. In any case, the (older) doctor is most likely going through the discordant review process. As it's been a week, I'd call his office. It is time to get some answers. Be pushy if you need to be. Get a follow up appointment scheduled and bring a list of questions (and perhaps a level headed friend/spouse who can take notes). What you want to leave that appointment with is a diagnosis of what the find was on imaging OR a plan to advance that goal. If you have any more questions, please do ask us.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2017 11:07PM MTwoman wrote: Muhreeyah, so sorry you are here with breast health concerns instead of just being able to enjoy your sweet baby! and of course you can hope for a b9 result - the chances are very good that what is going on is b9. You should always get new or concerning breast symptoms checked out by your doctor, but there are so many things that happen in breasts (especially breast feeding mommies' breasts) that are b9. Add to that the very low incidence of bc in women your age, and your chances of a b9 cause are very very good. Please note this information from the National Cancer Institute:  Your age group spans 15 years worth of women, and only represents 1.8% of the bc diagnoses in the US. So please do follow up, but don't go too far down the "what if" path just yet. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2017 03:19PM MTwoman wrote: So here's what I found. Several studies have indicated a "possible association" with inconsistent results. This study looked at whether SSRIs were linked with increased CNS metasteses - found it wasn't https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27289477 This study looked at whether SSRIs were linked to increased BC risk via altered prolactin levels - found it wasn't https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27165168 This is an interesting study, quite large, done in the UK. They suggested a slight increase in odds ratio (only 1.12) for SSRI use and breast cancer. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25934397 So the jury is still out. So far, there have not been conclusive reproducible findings. I think that the risks of a person with significant depression without the benefit of antidepressants is pretty significant. It seems to be another case of having to weigh out various risks from a personal risk tolerance perspective.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2017 09:30AM MTwoman wrote: Adelozier, I am not stressed out, just trying to help! :) "acoustic shadowing" refers to the fact that cancerous masses tend to be denser than the surrounding breast tissue, so when imaging "light" (in us it is actually waves, but the effect is the same) is passed through the breast the mass actually casts what looks like a shadow behind it on the film. NOT having acoustic shadowing is, then, good. As for increased blood flow, cancers typically require a blood supply of their own to grow, so they tend to show increased vascularity or blood flow. Not showing that is, again, good. These are the characteristics that they write in a report when they are seen. Yours didn't have them, so Lotusconnie is saying, that is a good sign. You should get your results soon! try your best to distract and relax :)

Posts.Content: May 3, 2017 09:36AM MTwoman wrote: There is nothing wrong with second opinions. You may find a better fit with another doctor (this one was "horrible"). And understanding what your bc consists of, and what the treatment implications are, is very important. You'll need a team, MO (medical oncologist), RO (radiation oncologist) and BS (breast surgeon) and perhaps a PS (plastic surgeon) or specialist pathologist. These folks will be the ones who help you understand your choices and carry out your treatment plan. This is the hardest part of the journey, right now. The knowing you have bc, but not knowing the details/extent, increases the fear and not being able to get started in treatment planning (until you have all of the preliminary info) means you're still stuck in the feeling powerless mode. Try good self care right now. Make sure you are eating, sleeping (get meds if you need them) and relaxing/distracting as best you can. Keeping yourself in good physical and mental condition will let you have a clear head for decision making and heal from procedures better. Start your notebook with copies of labs, reports, pathology etc. (the forums "just diagnosed and waiting for test results", "surgery, before during and after" and "IDC" will provide quite a bit of support and information when you are ready) If you start to feel overwhelmed, just focus on the next step, what is the next appointment or next decision and what do I need to do for that one thing? You can do this! We are here to help. ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2017 05:19PM MTwoman wrote: bowoky, there are women who have had lumps that didn't show up on mammo or us that have turned out each way; benign or malignant. Each imaging tool (mammo, us, mri) are best at "seeing" different things. (DJMammo would be better at explaining exactly which does what best) That's why they are usually taken together if one isn't sufficient. MRI is the best, but is expensive and more sensitive. Any suspicious finding on mri would then need to be biopsied, which would equate to many more women with benign findings getting biopsied. (and much more worry during the wait). So mri is usually reserved in the event of a finding not being clearly identified by mammo + us - which is your situation. The specialist is making recommendations based on standard protocols. You are going to have to decide whether you are going to follow the recommendations and whether you'll do it sooner, or wait. Sorry, but we each have to make those decisions for ourselves. I am sorry you find yourself in this confusing place!

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2017 11:26AM MTwoman wrote: Amanda, the risks/benefits are the reason that this is an individual recommendation, not standard of care. I had one too, that found additional small tumors that hadn't been seen by the diagnostic mammo or us (I presented with a palpable lump and the other areas were smaller and "hiding" in another area of my breast). If I hadn't had the mri, identified remaining DCIS and then had mx, I would have happily gone into radiation after my initial lx, thinking the DCIS was all gone and perhaps had an invasive recurrence (I was triple neg, so not on Tamox or AIs). If you need the MRI, as you've had other imaging that aren't definitive (or you have breast density or a history that warrants it) it could save your life. I understand your reluctance, and agree that there may not be " another alternative to finding (my) problem". Sorry!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2017 05:16PM MTwoman wrote: Isis, I am SO very sorry that you are having to go through this stigmatization and alienation from part of your treatment team, at the same time as you are preparing to go into surgery. How horrible for him not to have had an open and honest discussion with you about his concerns, instead of sending in his nurse to tell it to (at) you. Shame on him! Now, as for your question, I know that there have been women that I've heard from on these boards mention not using prescription pain meds after mx surgery. If you don't get enough responses on this forum, you could also try the "surgery, before, during and after" (but delete this one first so you don't have 2 different ones running and potentially getting the same info from the same people). I am also wondering about your feeling that you would have horrible withdrawal from short term use of opiates. I'm sure that your addiction could be triggered (I've worked with clients who struggled with addiction), and having support set up for yourself in anticipation of this would be very wise, but I'm not as sure that a post surgical injection or 2 and a day or two of opiates (which is all I actually used) would leave you withdrawing. Most likely you'd want a wash out period before you re-started your Suboxone. Personally, I'd want to have a quick consult with the provider of my Suboxone (many doctors are NOT familiar with how to use this medication) and discuss a plan to support your care, use of medications for pain control, and coordination of care (when to stop Sub., when to use opiates, when to stop opiates and then restart Subox.) and ask for your providers help in being on your treatment team. Then I'd have a come-to-Jesus meeting with my surgeon and discuss this wrinkle in your otherwise already made plan. You deserve care as we all do. Please don't let yourself be treated with any less respect than anyone else. If the line has somehow been drawn in the sand around taking opiates home, then talk to your surgeon about planning to stay in the hospital until your pain is well enough controlled to transition to over-the-counter pain meds. You can't heal properly if your pain and swelling cause more pain and swelling, that causes pain that causes swelling; and your surgeon knows this. so sorry!! ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2017 04:55PM MTwoman wrote: Ericka, as you are in health sciences, let me share a link with you: http://www.medpagetoday.com/radiology/diagnosticradiology/63779 this article is a write up of a radiology consortium analysis. It seems like you are one of the people that this applies to. Basically, our digital technology has gotten better; which is good. There has been an increase of over 11 people detected with bc per 1000 screened, since the digital mammo (improved sensitivity). Unfortunately, there has also been a 50% increase in the number of biopsies performed due to the increase in sensitivity (decreased specificity). There is now a call to improve the negative prognostic use of digital mammography so that we are able to catch more bc more quickly, but not put so many women through multiple biopsies and the anxiety that goes along with it. There are many, many women who go through multiple "finds" and biopsies to be told B9. In fact, 80% of BIRADS 4 biopsies are B9. BIRADS 4 is the lowest score where biopsy is warranted and insurance will cover it. so sorry you are going through this (again). I certainly realize that 'false-positives' might cause someone to be complacent, but your health is certainly worth vigilance :) There is something called the GAIL model, that could help you get some idea of your personal risk. Good luck!

Posts.Content: May 19, 2017 09:52PM MTwoman wrote: Tyllgod, So sorry you are going through a breast health scare. Now is the time to get on your steel-toed *ss kicking boots. Call your insurance company. Keep heading up the ladder until you get somebody who can get it done. When someone "can't help you", then ask to be transferred to someone who can or their boss. Keep going until you have what you need. I'm not saying that I think you have a malignancy, but your concerned medical provider wants you to have a procedure. In the situation you describe (mammo finding, unable to locate with us) it is best practice to get another imaging technology. Each technology is best at certain things. We don't typically use mri as the second source, because it is very sensitive (finds lots of stuff) but is not as specific (doesn't just find malignancies), which results in many women having biopsies (the vast majority will be B9). BUT IN YOUR CASE, where us is not adding any additional information, it is totally appropriate. Using two imaging technologies is standard of care for areas of concern. You need to push them. Sorry if that is difficult to ask, but sometimes we have to be our own advocate! You can do it! Let us know what's going on and how we can help! Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2017 04:49PM MTwoman wrote: Hi sable, sorry you're having trouble with the language from your report. Let me give you a link here: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/83/topics/858196?page=1#post_5033387 that is a thread on how to read your imaging report. The important passage, as it pertains to your report, is this, both oval and circumscribed are "good" descriptors, which is probably part of the reason they believe your mass appears b9. A BIRADS 3 score routinely recommends 6 month follow up to insure the area is stable, so that is consistent with the descriptors and recommendation. You can read more about complex vs complicated cysts here: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/complex-breast-cyst Basically, there are 3 types: simple (which is easy to distinguish on us, and is fluid filled), complicated (contain some debris or texture inside the well-defined cystic structure - the recommendation is usually 6 month follow up) and complex (which is sometimes called complex cystic mass or solid and cystic mass; so it isn't confused with complicated cyst - the recommendation is typically biopsy). Hope this helps. DJMammo may also swing by to add his more expert opinion.
Posts.Title: routine mammogram sable081 koshka1

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2017 09:04PM MTwoman wrote: sable, as discussed in the link I provided, "oval" and "circumscribed" are both GOOD terms (meaning not associated with malignancy) so things you shouldn't be concerned about. Complicated cyst is, again, NOT bad. It is a typical recommendation for a complicated cyst to be imaged again in 6 months, with the goal of making sure it is stable (not changing). So that recommendation that you got, fits the diagnostic impression of a complicated cyst - which is typically considered b9.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2017 10:49AM MTwoman wrote: CR - congrats on the negative biopsy results! What concerns me now is "my head began to think of the stories I've read of women with IBC who's biopsy's were originally negative to later have a positive one." Sometimes, when we've been in a situation where our anxiety is really high (like a health scare), it is hard to get the anxiety to go back down to "normal". When that happens, we can continue to focus on the thing we fear (which is now gone) instead of focusing on what we know to be true. As long as you focus on the thing that you fear, you'll continue to have the "feeling of doom". What we know to be true is that you've seen a dermatologist who examined you and said that you "absolutely do not have IBC" and that the rash was actually "looking better". What is also true is that (in order to make you feel better) she also did a punch biopsy to verify that you do not have IBC, and it came back negative for IBC. That the dermatologist said your rash is looking better means that it is NOT progressing in a rapid and aggressive way, like IBC does. So please try your best, when the fears start nagging at you, to go through the list of things you know to be true, focus on the rational and logical facts: I've seen a dermatologist who says I do not have IBC, I have a rash; and I've had a punch biopsy that indicates I do not have IBC. If you continue to struggle with the anxiety, then I do think an urgent referral to a counselor is in order; anxiety can consume your life and that would be an awful waste! Hoping your rash continues to clear and make it easier for you to breathe and relax again!!

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2017 11:18AM MTwoman wrote: Dark13, let me try to answer your questions as best I can, but I will also direct you to the surgery thread as there is quite a bit of good info there. will I be able to move around? I asked to be discharged the same day of my mx surgery (had the surgery at 7am and went home about 2pm) and after my surgeon rounded on me, he agreed. I did not have any recon at that time, and had no problems healing (I don't know if you have had any healing issues in the past, that might make a difference). I restricted my activities pretty significantly for a few days, but was wearing big sweaters (to cover my drain collection reservoir - similar to a very small canteen) with jeans and moving around pretty easily after the first few days. How do I use the washroom etc? I was not allowed to shower for quite awhile initially, but didn't have any problem using the bathroom as I only had umx, not bmx. My partner washed my hair for me in the kitchen sink, so that was helpful. How do I even get clothes on since i won't be able to lift my hands. I am envisioning lots of pain if any one can shed some light re after the surgery what to expect. If you are having bmx, then I imagine that your inconvenience will be more significant than umx. I was able to dress myself (again, the first couple of days I was in jammy pants and big soft button up fleecy tops or a bathrobe) without any assistance after surgery. I did stay with a friend (a doc who put a baby monitor in my room in case I needed help) but never needed her assistance. I would say that I had quite a bit of discomfort, but not "lots of pain". Now, I am told I have a high pain threshold, but I only took pain meds during the day for the first few days. After that, I took them at night for several more days and then I was on only OTCs. It was important for me (mentally) to get back to normal as soon as possible, which meant that I had goals set for myself to get back to work (I'm a therapist, so mainly sitting while at work) as quickly as I could. I was back at work within 2 weeks. Everyone is different in how quickly they heal, how they experience pain and how they recover. Do try to prepare yourself, but I'm hoping you find that your recovery is much easier than you are anticipating. ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2017 09:04AM MTwoman wrote: Worrywart, Zuerste, Herzlichen Gluekwunsch zu Ihren Resultaten! A complicated cyst is very similar to a simple cyst, it just contains some harmless debris as well as fluid. When the fluid is aspirated, it is quite common for the cyst to collapse. The typical recommendation for complicated cysts is short interval follow up (as was the recommendation in your case). https://radiopaedia.org/articles/complex-breast-cyst I would believe that they aspirated fluid and sent it to cytology because of your family history and to make extra sure you were not in the "0.3-2%" of complicated cysts that turn out to be bc. Now that they've done the aspiration and actually gotten b9 results AND the cyst has collapsed; I would encourage you to allow yourself to feel happy about it :) It is quite understandable that you have anxiety about bc, given your tremendous loss. Have you considered seeing a therapist? Working with someone could provide you with some relief from the awfulness that is anxiety. Beste Wuenshce fuer anhaltende Gesundheit!

Posts.Content: May 9, 2017 04:33PM MTwoman wrote: Jordan, do you have a copy of the written report? If so, and you post it here, it might help us be more helpful to you. As far as the biopsy results, if they came back "normal breast tissue", then it would be more worrisome that they had missed the spot entirely, but they did find "infection" (in whatever clinical language they used). If that "infection" and the resulting changes explain what the radiologist imaged, then that would leave me less likely to think a second opinion is necessary. did the radiologist not explain how the "infection" was responsible for your Mom's findings? I think you are always entitled to a second opinion, if you don't feel like the presenting issue wasn't thoroughly managed and sufficiently explained to you. If you do that, you should absolutely have the images (you are legally entitled to a copy on disc) as well as the written report (not the patient letter) from the first opinion, to take with you to your second opinion. That way, the second opinion has something to compare. I'd follow up with your Mom's PCP, discuss what happened, and then get a referral for a second opinion.

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2017 03:19PM MTwoman wrote: Anita, what I'd also recommend is that you get a copy of your written imaging report (not the patient letter). The parts that you want to pay attention to are the impression, recommendations and BIRADS score. Those things might explain why your doctor was recommending 6 months. The language that you used above is not sufficient to be able to have a good understanding of whether your finding has concerning characteristics, but "oval" isn't concerning. BIRADS scores correlate to positive predictive values and that also informs you not only about the associated risk but what the standard recommendations are. It is good practice to get copies of your imaging reports and images (on cd). Good luck with your second!

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2017 09:58AM MTwoman wrote: Anita, interesting article. The purpose of the study was "to assess the utility and pathological results" from tomo, when the finding was occult to mammo and us. They found that there was utility (recommended performing DBT when available) and that approx. 21% of the 38 findings (which, lets be honest, 38 is a pretty small n) were malignant. I don't think, however, that you can generalize these findings to assume that "masses [that] are not detected on ultrasounds and end up as cancerous (25%) or suspicious (an additional 25%)." It was a small retrospective review. I know that as a researcher, you want to plow through the literature and make sense of things. (I was a health researcher for some years, so I know the feeling) I have found some others that have different percentages (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26148173 and https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25575115). IMO, the takeaway message is to continue to pursue this finding until you have a firm diagnosis. Dig your heels in. Push for an answer. Let us know how we can help.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2017 03:00PM MTwoman wrote: alonenscared, a cyst and tumor are 2 completely different things and would look completely different on ultra sound. When there is an identifiable finding that has less than a 2% chance of being cancer it isn't biopsied. There are standards of care that medical professionals follow. Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2017 02:43PM MTwoman wrote: In addition to the 2 suggestions above, you may want to meet with an Internal Medicine doc. The majority of what you've described is NOT BREAST RELATED. You were even working towards trying to figure out what was going on with a neurologist, and seemed to have gotten distracted by the phenomenon happening in your breasts. It isn't uncommon for women to have skin issues on their breasts and become convinced that it is bc and seek treatment from an OB/GYN, Radiologist and BS, when in the end a Dermatologist is what's needed. The same may be true here. Whatever is causing yout pain should be found, but it doesn't mean that it will be found in your breast tissue. There is a strong possibility that the mri might "find" things in your breasts, as it is very sensitive. This might even lead to biopsies (70-80% of which are b9). But as DJMammo has suggested, if you actually had metastatic bc at the age of 28, it would be extraordinarily unusual. In fact,  Please note that the category of women to which you belong comprises 15 years worth of women and represents only 1.8% of all the bc diagnosed in the US. You don't seem to be "brushed off" by the doctors. They've done exams and ordered imaging studies. You just may be seeing the wrong kind of doctor because it isn't breast related. Hoping you get answers soon. Do please let us know what the mri finds.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2017 01:18PM MTwoman wrote: So sorry you find yourself here jules, with questions and concerns. This thread hasn't been active since 2009, but I can answer some of your questions. BIRADS 4c has a positive predictive value of 79%, which means that in 79% of the time a BIRADS 4c finding is malignant. Notice that isn't 100%, so there is still room for a b9 pathology result, but given the radiologist's impression, I would encourage you to try and prepare yourself mentally for a bc diagnosis, continuing to hope that it isn't. I guess I'm not sure whether it really matters whether a surgeon (who does some biopsies) is better than the Radiologist (who does lots of biopsies), but if you already have your biopsy scheduled, that point is mute. I would ask them on Thursday when they expect to get your pathology results back, and also if they will insist on you having a follow up appointment to get the results, or if they will give them over the phone. (different facilities have different protocols and it helps to set expectations) If they want you to have a follow up appointment, I would encourage you to bring someone with you as it can be difficult to remember to ask questions and take in all of the information given - even with b9 results (in that case there will be short interval follow up, or sometimes even removal is recommended). That person can be there to support or celebrate with you. Sending you positive thoughts for b9 results.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2017 04:43PM MTwoman wrote: If you had one 2 months ago, and nothing was seen, the surgeon may not want to order the same thing so quickly again either. Using the same technology to re-image something so quickly is not typical. Usually, if they want another image, it is in 6 months to compare the findings to see if they are stable. Shorter time than that isn't long enough to be certain. But if they didn't find anything, there is no reason to believe that they will suddenly find something 2 months later. The unfortunate fact, Littlewhite, is that many women have breast pain where no cause can be found. There is a radiologist who comments on these boards, who has said that breast pain was the number one presenting concern at his old clinic and that many women didn't have any cause that could be found. so it could be something, and should most definitely be checked out. But if nothing is found by several different imaging technologies (like mammo plus ultra sound or mri), then there is a point at which the answer is, we don't know what is causing it. I will be interested to hear what your surgeon says. If you get a copy of your report from the imaging 2 months ago and post that language, it may let us be more helpful. Please do keep us informed and let us know if there is anything else that you need from us.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2017 08:50AM MTwoman wrote: littlewhite, the specialist saw your indentation line and did an exam. She "did not find anything abnormal". So, you've got 2 options: the first is to try and focus on what the expert told you. to trust her, her education, training and experience. If you don't believe her to be competent, or that she somehow didn't fully examine or appreciate your concerns, then your second option is to get a second opinion. What doesn't seem like a good choice is to just dwell on your anxiety and stay hyper-focused on every little change in your breast. You need to find a balance of noticing, but not being irrational about it. You need to notice changes, so that you can present them for a medical workup when necessary. But you need to remain rational so that you can hear and believe credible experts when they examine you and give you their opinions. Your issue is starting to sound more like anxiety and less like a breast concern. Have you thought about talking to your doctor about your anxiety? Anxiety can cause an awful amount of havoc in your life. Good luck and I'm glad you got B9 results.
